verb.description: Move slowly and carefully in order to avoid being heard or noticed.
examples: he crept downstairs, hardly making any noise
they were taught how to creep up on an enemy

verb.description: (of an unwanted and negative characteristic or fact) occur or develop gradually and almost imperceptibly.

noun.description: Slow movement, especially at a steady but almost imperceptible pace.
examples: an attempt to prevent this slow creep of costs

phrases: If this news doesn't give you the creeps then you aren't thinking clearly.
She gets this look on her face that gives me the creeps, and I'm not the only one that feels that way.
The entire situation gave her the creeps, but she refused to become paralysed with fear.
It gives me the creeps sometimes to look through the files.
The sight of Chinese acupuncture, in particular, still gives me the creeps.
an anonymous note like that would creep me out
Those movies creep me out, I tell her.
These written professions of love completely creep me out.
The TV version, made in 1975, still creeps me out from the corners of my memory.
Unfortunately, lately he's been creeping me out.
origin: Old English crÄ“opan move with the body close to the ground, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kruipen. Sense 1 of the verb dates from Middle English.
